<@U091EBYSU>: can u point me to the documentation on how i can write adapters to support my enum or `Date` or `DateTime` objets?

<@U04UBTWEE>: at the moment our annotation processor does not support custom types <https://github.com/pushtorefresh/storio/issues/475>

1. I'll work on it for StorIO 1.7.0!
2. Annotation processor is not required part of StorIO, you always can write custom Put/Get/Delete resolvers with any implementation that you need, that's current way to handle custom types in the entities
3. You can add a package private field just for serialization! I mean, you can provide `Date`/`DateTime` to the public usage but internally store it as `long` etc and mark it with `@StorIOSQLiteColumn` annotation!

attachments.title: Support for custom field types on generated resolvers Â· Issue #475 Â· pushtorefresh/storio Â· GitHub

text: <@U091EBYSU>: thanks, do fields have to be package private or can they be public ?
<@U04UBTWEE>: just not `private` so generated code could access them without reflection: `package private` (empty), `public` or `protected` is okay!

<@U091EBYSU>: iâ€™ve historically used DD, with find() methods to get related objects on my entity.. whats a neat way to do that with storIO?
only thing i can think of is a static variable of the db handle

<@U04UBTWEE>: StorIO is not ORM, so it does not generate any kind of SQL for you, it will be a regular query to the db

```
storIOSQLite
  .get()
  .listOfObjects(Your.class) // or cursor()
  .withQuery(Query.builder() // btw, Queries are immutable so you can save and share them, see sample app
    ...)
  .prepare()
  .createObservable() // or executeAsBlocking()
```
i did it! iâ€™m fully integrated with StorIO.. and sugarOrm free
whats the easiest way to blow away my database on startup while im in heavy development without going into the app settings and clearing data?
<@U091EBYSU>: i often like going `object.getListOfRelatedObjects()` how can i organise my code to achieve this?

<@U04UBTWEE>: it's totally up to you! Choose any way that fits your needs. 

1. Make kind of relations between entities and resolve related entities at time of retrieving parent entity, for example retrieve all tweets of the user at time of retrieving user from db.
2. Just provide a method to from the entity to do this, example  `someUser.getTweets(storIOSQLite)` which will use retrieve all tweets for this user.

Does anyone here have experience with Android Volley?
I'd like to leverage Volley's cache for offline access, however, I get a network connection error when I'm offline.
I can see that responses are being added to the cache.
are you certain your servers headers have cache responses?

I dont use volley but thats general an issue you see if the content is not indicating it should be cached the network layer will just keep assuming it has to download it again if the headers of the next request changed
or in this case it cant even get that far
<@U055GGAHS>: I'm sure they do not, however I sorta monkey patched the response by overriding `parseNetworkResponse`.
And I've stepped through the caching logic, I can see the responses being added to the cache.

<@U04UBTWEE> 1 can be achieved with custom GetResolver that maps the results into entity with combination of objects, something like `UserWithTweets`. You then make query with `join` and parse `User` and `Tweets` separately and combining them into one and returning it as a result.

<@U04UBTWEE> basic solution if you need to deal with combined entity (btw, usually we just try to avoid it) - create it as separate entity!
